title.narrative: To provide lifesaving multisectoral response services for GBV survivors, including clinical management of rape, health and psychosocial support and case management.

description.narrative: The main objective of this project is to provide lifesaving multisectoral response services for GBV survivors. This UNFPA project provides 1) deploys GBV specialists to provide immediate technical support, 2) provides psychological care for GBV survivors within the Women and Girls Safe Spaces (WGSS) and remotely, 3) provides cash assistance to women at risk, and 4) establishes protection referral pathways among other activities. The project provides life-saving assistance to 12,000 people, including 79 men, 7,821 women, 5,000 children, and 300 persons with disabilities.

owner-org.narrative: UN OCHA Central Emergency Response Fund (CERF)

organisation.narrative: UN Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs (OCHA)

mailing-address.narrative: United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs (OCHA), Central Emergency Response Fund (CERF), 2 United Nations Plaza (DC2), East 44th street (13th floor), United Nations, New York, USA

description.narrative: Disbursement to CERF Project To provide lifesaving multisectoral response services for GBV survivors, including clinical management of rape, health and psychosocial support and case management.

title.narrative: RESIDENT / HUMANITARIAN COORDINATOR REPORT ON THE USE OF CERF FUNDS HONDURAS UNDERFUNDED EMERGENCIES ECONOMIC DISRUPTION 2022

condition.narrative: CERF funding is based on an agreed proposal, including specific planned outcomes and outputs.

description.narrative: GBV response teams, first line health responders and communities enhance its capacity to respond to the needs of GBV survivors during emergencies, by providing psychological first aid and safely referring them to accessible and confidential, survivor centered life-saving services
# of people within community response teams/groups who know basic GBV concepts, how to make safe referrals to health facilities and mitigate GBV risks within the community
# of professionals who know and ethically implement the care strategy for survivors of GBV in situations of forced displacement and migration
SP.3 Number of health care providers receiving training on the minimum emergency response package for sexual and reproductive health

Provision of accessible, confidential, survivor-centered services to address GBV in line with the Inter-Agency Standards for GBV in Emergency Programming, establishment of safe entry points for case management and psychosocial support services, including safe spaces for women and girls, remote services, mobile teams during emergencies, for migrant and displaced women and girls.
Cash.1a Number of people receiving multi-purpose CASH
Cash.1b Total value of multi-purpose cash distributed in USD

Number Of GBV survivors (disaggregated by age, sex, ethnic origin, disability condition, human mobility situation) who completed a feedback surveys, who are satisfied with the Case Management services (90% target)
PS.1a Number of people accessing women- and girl-friendly safe spaces and/or centres
PS.2 Number of people benefitting from core GBV services (e.g. case management, psycho-social support, clinical management of rape, PEP, etc.)

Strengthen or set up prevention and Risk mitigation strategies, mechanisms, and initiatives in support community-based interventions in line with IASC principles and guidelines, including life-saving protection information
# of people surveyed within the community who have received key messages on GBV and accessed life-saving information (disaggregated by age, gender, ethnicity, human mobility status, disability)
# of women leaders and other women in the community who safely accessed life-saving information on GBV and are aware of existing referral and protection mechanisms for survivors
Number of people accessing protection referral pathways (for GBV)
PP.1a Number of protection referral pathways established and regularly updated (for GBV)
